question.text: "Every species has a right to live". What kind of value implies the conservation of biodiversity?

solution.text: The Convention on biological diversity emerged out of a universal consensus that biodiversity is of immense value to mankind. Although the report adopted the definition of the Convention on biological diversity, it reviews the concept of biodiversity as applied to genes, microbes, ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The ethics of biodiversity argues that these facts should inspire careful reflection and action in the society, which must learn from earth's vast diversity in order to help conserve the natural and social diversity of our planet. Nature has given this planet to all the life forms and we (Human) by any means have no right to dispose other organisms from its place is the core of ethical aspect for bio-diversity.
